chapter.title: TDF Operating System Basics
chapter.para: It is very plain to see that, when initiated, the TDF operating system displays only a command prompt. As there is graphical interface bundled with the operating system, this will be the only way in which commands may be input to the system for processing.

Inputting commands to be processed is very simple. The following prompt (or something very similar) should be initially displayed on the screen:
tdf:$
At this prompt, you may simply type in the desired command to be processed (for information about the various commands offered in the TDF operating system, simply type "help" or refer to the "Commands" chapter of this manual). To terminate the system, simply type "exit" at the prompt.

The commands typed into the prompt have certain restrictions as far as formatting goes. For example, all of the commands are case sensitive and must be typed in all lower-case (for example, you cannot process "EXIT", but you may process "exit"). Another restriction is that the commands may not exceed 256 characters in length (not that you'll ever need that much buffer space).

Some commands implemented in the TDF operating system have arguments that may be passed, such that they will perform more specific processes (for example, date). To pass arguments to these commands, you must specify the flag and, if applicable, the value of the argument. For example, to set the date, the following command may be run:
tdf:$ date -s 2009
